text.b: Albany High School Conceptual Ed Spec
Albany High School Conceptual Ed Spec
Vision Statement – The New Albany HS

page.text: The new Albany High School will be an inspiring place for learning, where
smaller communi9es make up the whole and nurture a welcoming feeling
of belonging and empowerment – celebra9ng the mosaic of diversity that
walks through its doors each day.
The school will fully support a program that is Albany-­‐student-­‐
focused, addressing the unique needs of the majority while oﬀering
expanded opportuni9es for students to discover their personal
talents and embark upon their journey toward achieving their
It will feel relevant to students by celebra9ng their achievements and
highligh9ng their work – integra9ng college and career opportuni9es
for all and inspiring them to believe in their own ability to succeed.
It will provide places for adults and learners to build rela9onships that
transcend both the academic day and the campus.
And it will proudly stand as a constant reminder that Albany students
are capable and worthy of greatness – deserving of the very best
their community can give to them.
The Albany High School is a place where the possibili9es are nearly endless.
If you want to achieve something at Albany High, the feeling is that you can
achieve it by taking advantage of the many and varied opportuni9es that
await the best and brightest among students. It is no secret, however, that
this strength may be the school’s most profound weakness, somewhat
dilu9ng its inﬂuence over the lives of the majority of students who struggle
with the basics. The large numbers of students that get lost in the struggle
are not able to take advantage of the opportuni9es. This paradox is seen as
an obstacle that dwarfs the inﬂuence of any one leader, one teacher, one
ac9vist or one consultant. It will be overcome by the collec9ve courage of
an en9re leadership teams and community – School Board,
We publicly acknowledge the enormity of the task ahead – which requires

text.b: Albany High School Conceptual Ed Spec

page.text: more than simply geJng more students to graduate in four years. That, in itself, is
an enormous task – yet this is not the school’s greatest challenge. Many agree that
the greatest challenge is building the capacity within the ins9tu9on to support the
unique needs of today’s Albany High School student, while adap9ng to
needs of the students of tomorrow. This requires more than simply the addi9on or
subtrac9on of an educa9onal program or the implementa9on of Small Learning
Communi9es. It will demand a fundamental shiN in the way the community views
high school educa9on – internally and externally.
Based on our research, there is a community of thought around the following vision
1.The school is too big and must be either broken up into smaller schools or
schools within schools -­‐ crea9ng learning communi9es. This is more than
simply an issue of numbers, however. It is an issue of rela9onships. Of course,
forming meaningful peer-­‐to-­‐peer and adult-­‐student rela9onships is
inextricably linked to the number of students within Albany High. All Small
Learning Communi9es (SLCs) are not created equal. It is a general consensus
that smaller SLCs could beneﬁt students and faculty alike, bringing them
together in an area that minimizes student movement within the facility and is
in close proximity to the school’s core func9ons and supports. (i.e., gym,
cafeteria, centralized college and career center, etc.). These SLCs need to
accommodate all core subjects, relevant thema9c elec9ves, areas for
socializa9on and project-­‐based learning, and administra9ve oversight that is
2.The school must be laser-­‐focused on addressing the whole child. This means
that the commitment of the adults must go beyond the classroom – in fact,
beyond the walls of the school or the campus grounds. It must reach into the
home. All students need to have an adult connec9on that reaches beyond
their academic life and beyond the academic day. Ideally,
should extend into the home, with the adult (mentor, advisor, etc.) having feet
under the table in the home at some point during the school year.
3.The breadth of the course oﬀerings at the school can, at 9mes, be at odds with
the need for the school to be focused on the core. Some of these resources

text.b: Albany High School Conceptual Ed Spec

page.text: must be redirected to equip the SLCs with the core and support services
necessary to address the needs of the majority. The scaﬀolding of those
services needs to start in 9th grade as a bridge from the middle school
program to the high school program. That is changing. (The superintendent

text.i: has made high school readiness and secondary transforma6on

page.text: her academic plan.) Providing triage in the ﬁrst high school semester may be
achieved through a 9th Grade Learning Community approach designed to
provide intense interven9on before the student is lost among 2,400 others.
There is support for examining how this might work in Albany. Subsequent
high school years will build upon the rela9onships forged in the ninth grade,
where students can then make choices that will aﬀect the next three years at
the high school level. Currently, many make these choices in middle school
with li\le or no knowledge of why they are making the choice. For many
students, the main driver of the choice seems to be
not necessarily what interests them, or more importantly, what they believe
4.Helping students discover relevance goes hand in glove with keeping students
in school. For many, a treasure trove of relevance is in the world of Career
and Technical Educa9on (CTE), which is hindered by its current loca9on being
oﬀ-­‐sire and isolated from the main campus. The current design is contrary to
the new vision. CTE is seen as being at the center of the new Albany High
School’s mission to create a program that is relevant to students and that
leads to a des9na9on students can envision even before star9ng the
CTE should be located at the very core of all
ac9vity. It will be a highlight as it prominently sits at the center of common
walkways where students can see educa9on come to life in projects and
excitement. As one of our community leaders said in our visioning session:
“Students need to see and understand career opportuni6es.” Furthermore,
the programs that can be more eﬀec9vely run outside of the school, should
be. Opportuni9es should not be limited by the physical structure. The
building should not be – and cannot be – the only place where high school
students are educated in a global community. These course oﬀerings must be
ﬂuid and be aligned with high demand career opportuni9es of the day and
poten9al demand for tomorrow. This will call for ﬂexible-­‐use spaces that can

text.b: Albany High School Conceptual Ed Spec

page.text: be transformed without taking down walls and altering size.
5.Empowerment is a key issue for the
vision as well. Students need to feel as if
they are in control of their own des9ny – with personal control that evolves as
they accede to the next level. That empowerment may include having career
training and externship opportuni9es as part of their junior and senior years,
will certainly be reﬂected in the design of the spaces
6.By the 9me students get to their senior year, the new Albany High School
should be almost indis9nguishable from the college experience. In other
words, if students have progressed up to that point, they should be able to
access college courses and resources right on campus. While this model may
not be preferred by all (some may want to send students to the college
campus), this seems to be the best model from a ﬁnancial standpoint for all
par9es. Colleges are able to deliver programs on the high school campus far
more cost-­‐eﬀec9vely than on their campuses. As one campus president said:

text.i: “The moment your student steps on my campus, I am forced to charge them

page.text: our tui6on rates....Integra6ng college into the high school is the future.” This
will call for moving toward a model in which
spaces will become dual use for
both high school and college courses (e.g., science labs) -­‐ being
ﬁt out with that in mind.
7.Not all oﬀ campus experiences should have to be oﬀ-­‐campus. Through
technology, specially equipped rooms should be set aside to bring the
experience to students. Distance Learning Labs and Educa9onal Technology
labs that incorporate interac9ve opportuni9es should be strategically located
at the school’s public core so that they can also be used for parent and adult
8.The new Albany High School needs to become the central community resource
for community educa9on – student, parent and adult learning. Mul9-­‐use
rooms need to be designed to ﬁt these needs. This would
deliver services six days a week, 18-­‐hours a
day, 12-­‐months a year in spaces that are ﬂexible and accessible enough to
deliver varied programs at oﬀ-­‐hours. Expanding paren9ng programs and
engaging them in how to assist their children to succeed needs to have a

text.b: Albany High School Conceptual Ed Spec

page.text: special place in the program and campus of the new school.
9.Classrooms need to reﬂect the needs of a fully integrated program – where
students with an IEP are spending the majority of their day in the general
popula9on. This has space implica9ons, since mul9ple adults (co-­‐teaching,
consultants) will be in a classroom together with the students. These classes
typically will be larger as well. In some cases, the tradi9onal rec9linear 770
square foot classroom may no longer serve this popula9on well. Having space
small group learning right inside or juxtaposed to the classroom might
10.Self-­‐contained special educa9on rooms needed to be integrated into each
Small Learning Community so that if socializa9on is possible with the general
popula9on it can happen in a smaller and familiar group. Small group rooms
for resource and pull-­‐out should also be integrated into the SLC. Specially
equipped rooms for the developmentally disabled should be closer to the core
11.A key factor in crea9ng the proper learning climate is security. The new design
must tread the ﬁne line between crea9ng an ins9tu9onal-­‐like atmosphere and
achieving both the appearance, and func9on of a secure environment. In the
visioning sessions, all agree that safety and security are priority issues;
however, there is also a belief that the design must be inspiring – both inside
and out. The design must achieve perceived and func9onal security while also
clearly expressing a commitment to relevance, inspira9on, and student
empowerment. This will require, at once, a level of “transparency” that will
inspire and translucency that will protect.
12.The new High School will be supported by a “techno-­‐sphere,” as it were, that
will be as integrated as the air. Every part of the facility will have accessible,
usable and scalable technological resources to support with pedagogical
13.The extra-­‐ and co-­‐curricular opportuni9es will be fully supported by both the
14.The design and construc9on of the new high school will be ﬂexible enough to
evolve with the changing needs of students and community by focusing on
core principles that transcend any single genera9on or educa9onal trend.

text.b: Albany High School Conceptual Ed Spec
I N T R O D U C T I O N

page.text: These Conceptual Educa9onal Speciﬁca9ons (Ed Specs) serve as a planning guide
for the architect and others responsible for the conceptual design of the City of
These speciﬁca9ons also can be termed a Program of Requirements (POR) for the
work being done at the high school. The program embodied in these
speciﬁca9ons provides general and adequate details for proposed spaces to begin
to conceptualize what the school might look like when ﬁnally constructed. While
quite detailed, these Conceptual Ed Specs only form the beginning of the design
conversa9on – the details of which will be resolved aNer a referendum is
successful some9me in the late fall of 2014.
This document a\empts to capture what will be needed in a school building to
accommodate the future program an9cipated at the Albany High School.
An9cipa9ng a program that has not yet been delivered is no small task. Much
about the current program is currently changing at the school and has yet to
change, while both personnel and plans will likely be very diﬀerent by the 9me
the new school is opened some9me in 2019 or 2020. Therefore, this document
does not a\empt to change the program or micromanage the will of the Board of
Educa9on or administra9on. Quite to the contrary, this document a\empts to
express the will of all key stakeholders by incorpora9ng foreseeable and
sustainable elements of a desired educa9onal framework within its speciﬁca9ons.

text.b: V I S I O N I N G P R O C E S S

page.text: To assist planners in looking ahead, an 18-­‐month Visioning Process was
completed involving stakeholder groups from all over the community – both
internally and externally. Open forums, structured par9cipatory events, focus
groups, Visioning Sessions, small group mee9ngs and personal interviews all were
held – puJng faces to quan9ta9ve data that was gathered through targeted
online surveys. On January 7, 2014, the City of Albany Board of Educa9on

text.b: Albany High School Conceptual Ed Spec

page.text: adopted a Vision for the new Albany High School. The ﬁnal 14 Vision Elements
narrowed the planning possibili9es considerably and contained sustainable
principles that are meant to transcend both 9me, personnel and future

text.b: C O N C E P T U A L E D U C A T I O N A L S P E C I F I C A T I O N S

page.text: These Ed Specs an9cipate future space needs – the quan9ty, typology, size and
juxtaposi9ons. In a school as complex as a large urban high school, this is a key
step before any design begins. For example, one issue that must be resolved
before any design begins is how many teaching sta9ons are needed to
accommodate future enrollments. This seems like a straighnorward issue un9l
one begins to factor in: 1) poten9al future growth, 2) retaining more students as
the gradua9on rate increases and the dropout rate declines, and 3) trying to
“read the tea leaves” about the future of local charter high schools. Add to this
the natural inﬂux of new students upon the opening of a brand new high school
and the ﬁnal enrollment numbers become much diﬀerent than what a quick
analysis might compute. These Conceptual Educa9onal Speciﬁca9ons an9cipate
the need for a school to accommodate 3,098 students at a 75% u9liza9on rate,
which is a foreseeable average rate that is typical at high schools around the

text.b: C A P A C I T Y C A L C U L A T I O N S

page.text: The current Albany High School has a capacity of 1,800 at a 75% u9liza9on rate.
When Abrookin is ﬁgured into the equa9on, the capacity ﬁgure increases to
1,987. (For the purpose of this calcula9on, 10 program spaces at Abrookin are
being counted at a 75% u9liza9on rate with a class size of 25.)
At the high school proper, 96 teaching sta9ons are being counted for capacity.
Here is how it breaks down:

text.b: 41 of 96 teaching sta<ons are undersized, falling between 600-­‐770 SF
Anything below 600 SF (770 is the state minimum for a regula<on sized
teaching sta<on) was leT oﬀ the calcula<on
Albany High School Conceptual Ed Spec
Using an average class size of 25, the current building capacity is 2,040 at
an 85% u<liza<on rate and 1800 at the more tradi<onal 75% u<liza<on

page.text: If you add 16 addi9onal teaching sta9ons that are closer to 500 SF (many
internal), the total teaching sta9ons counted for capacity comes to 112. That
brings the current capacity of the building to 2,380 at an 85% u9liza9on rate and
2,100 at a u9liza9on rate of the more tradi9onal 75% rate. With Abrookin, that
number increases by 187 to 2,287 at a 75% u9liza9on rate.

text.b: E X P R E S S I N G T H E V I S I O N

page.text: This Conceptual Educa9onal Speciﬁca9ons are an expression of the Board’s
Vision as interpreted by the stakeholders who have been involved in the Ed Spec
process, which was built en9rely upon the founda9on of the Vision document. In
July, 2013, students worked together in a pre-­‐Ed Spec mee9ng to discuss the
implementa9on of Small Learning Communi9es at the new school. On August 1,
2013, a similar discussion was facilitated with internal and external stakeholders.
On October 1, 2013, a high powered group of stakeholders including leaders from
community organiza9ons and higher educa9on ins9tu9ons, parents,
administrators, teachers, et. al, spent a half day together reﬁning the vision
elements and reinforcing much of ﬁndings of the previous eight months.
ANer the Board’s approval of the Vision Framework, an Educa9onal Speciﬁca9on
workshop was held January 8, 2014, where a group of administrators, teachers,
support staﬀ, parents and students came together to assess how a future
building could support the desired program within the parameters of the Vision
One of the key elements of the Conceptual Ed Spec addresses three components
Vision Element #1 calls for the establishment of smaller schools or
Vision Element #3 calls for targe9ng the incoming freshmen popula9on

text.b: Albany High School Conceptual Ed Spec

page.text: Vision Element #6 calls for a higher level of independence and
oﬀerings for upper level students in an environment that is essen9ally
The Conceptual Ed Specs express these three vision elements in the form of a
Lower High School (9th and 10th grades) and Upper High School (11th and 12th
grades). The group concluded that Vision Element #1 & 3 could only be
expressed by addressing the needs of incoming freshmen within a smaller
learning community with very a proac9ve program that provides unique
transi9onal supports while giving students incen9ves to reach for higher levels.
(These supports would target the unique needs of freshmen and, no doubt, could
not be replicated school-­‐wide due to logical budgetary constraints.)
Those incen9ves would likely include exploring a “Career Pathway” that could be
pursued in the upper grades – perhaps embarking on the pathway as early as
10th grade. This explora9on might allow freshmen to survey career and technical
possibili9es while having the support to discover their strengths so as to make a
successful Career Pathway (or thema9c academy) choice. This might provide
some students with the incen9ve to reach the next level as they move into
grades where they could pursue their desired career path.

text.b: E S C H E W I N G A F R E S H M E N A C A D E M Y

page.text: While a Freshmen Academy was discussed and debated at the January 8, 2014,
session, the more heterogeneous approach (grouping 9th and 10th) at the lower
grades was embraced for the following reasons, among others:
PuJng freshmen together in the largest learning community as one group
could result in student and teacher burnout – students leN without
posi9ve older role models and teachers fa9gued by the some9mes
overwhelming task of dealing exclusively with incoming freshmen and
older students who had been retained.
Advanced students would either have to be held back by the limita9ons of
a Freshmen Academy or take their advanced classes elsewhere – both
inevitably being bad possibili9es that would either limit the advanced

text.b: Albany High School Conceptual Ed Spec

page.text: student or remove that student as a posi9ve role model for other
freshmen in the community where they are needed most.
Students being retained for one or more courses would have to remain in
the Freshmen Academy or return to the community for the repeated
course, s9gma9zing them and presumably giving them added incen9ve to
A broader array of elec9ves could be oﬀered with the scale of having both
More support could be assigned to the community and become more
ﬂexible by being deployed where needed.
Students would become familiar with administrators, teachers and
supports that could follow them in the community for at least two years.
Be\er curriculum ar9cula9on from 9th grade to 10th grade might beneﬁt
teachers and students alike, making the most of employing ver9cal
Allowing for the poten9al of informal “looping” in 9th and 10th grades
where teachers may alternate assignments from year to year, thus
crea9ng a two-­‐year con9nuum for some students in certain subject areas.
Other Vision elements addressed in the Conceptual Ed Specs include crea9ng a
higher level, more college-­‐like experience for the Upper High School, which
would bring 11th & 12th graders together presumably in smaller numbers as
older students take advantage of opportuni9es outside the school. This expresses
the future vision found in Vision Elements #5 & 6.
Bridging the Lower and Upper Schools is Career Technical Educa9on, which will
be a centerpiece of the new high school – fully integrated at its core and within
some of its small learning communi9es, where appropriate. Career Pathway
teaching sta9ons are incorporated into every small learning community in both
the Lower and Upper schools, while the most inspiring programs will be most
visible to all at the very core of the school in more transparent spaces. This is an
expression of Vision Element #5, which calls for the full integra9on of inspiring
CTE programming at the core of the new school.

text.b: Albany High School Conceptual Ed Spec
O V E R V I E W O F P R O C E S S T I M E L I N E

page.text: January-­‐May 2013 – District engages more than 250 parents, community members, students,
staﬀ and community leaders in individual and small-­‐group focus sessions designed to gather
input on the academic, social-­‐emo9onal and extracurricular needs central to the process of
planning for a new or renovated high school. These sessions included the following groups:
May-­‐August 2013 – More than 200 respond to an online survey to provide input and
feedback on the future of Albany High.
June 10, 2013 – Approximately 75 community members a\end a town hall mee9ng to discuss
programs and services that would be oﬀered in a new or renovated high school.
June 25, 2013 – Approximately 100 community members, students, staﬀ and stakeholders
par9cipate in the Re-­‐Imagining Albany High School Summit.
July 18, 2013 – Approximately 20 Albany High and middle-­‐school students par9cipate in an
Aug. 1, 2013 – Approximately 30 Albany High staﬀ members and students par9cipate in an
Oct. 1, 2013 – Approximately 40 community members, higher-­‐educa9on leaders, staﬀ and
parents par9cipate in a secondary-­‐transforma9on planning mee9ng.
Nov. 21, 2013 – Board discusses preliminary High School Vision document.
Dec. 19, 2013 – Board discusses and revises the High School Vision document.
Jan. 6, 2014 – Board approves the High School Vision document.
Jan. 8, 2014 – Approximately 50 staﬀ, students and parents par9cipate in the Educa9onal
January-­‐February 2014 – Educa9onal Legacy Planning Group prepares educa9onal
speciﬁca9ons and space-­‐rela9onship diagram and preliminary design concepts.
March-­‐May 2014 – CSArch prepares ini9al preliminary design concepts. During this 9me
period dialog with the board was not on the schedule as the focus was the budget process.
June 5, 2014 – Board presenta9on of ini9al preliminary design concepts
June 16, 2014 – Board Facili9es Commi\ee reviews and discusses preliminary design concepts
June 18, 2014 – Approximately 100 community members, students, staﬀ and stakeholders
par9cipate in the Albany High School Concept Design Forum, providing feedback on the

text.b: Albany High School Conceptual Ed Spec

page.text: The above diagram expresses critical relationships and relative sizes of essential spaces. It is a first draft intended

text.b: to express enough information to form a conceptual framework for the new Albany High School. It is not meant

page.text: to be used for a final design. The diagram represents an ideal concept – both in the number of spaces represented
and the adjacencies of those spaces. It does not express floor distinctions, nor does it account for the unique geometry
of the buildings being renovated and/or repurposed.

text.b: Critical conceptual features of the desired Albany High School are:

page.text: The high school is divided into an “Upper High School” and “Lower High School,” with smaller learning
communities further dividing the two distinctive levels.
The Lower High School is made up of three
is designed for the larger freshman class of incoming 9th graders (and perhaps some repeaters). SLC #2 &
SLC #3, which are loosely connected to SLC #1, form the balance of the Lower High School
SLC #2 and #3 are smaller communities serving advanced 9th
The Upper High School is made up of two Small Learning Communities (SLCs) and designed to address the
needs of advanced 10th graders, 11th and 12th graders, sharing administrative and student support services.
Two student entrances are envisioned – one each for the upper and lower schools. Those entrances will be
shut down after arrival to allow for a single point of public entry into the building.
A Welcome Center, Library/Media Center, Auditorium, Student Health Center, Parent Resource Room and
Teacher Center all are near the entrance of the school and/or are available for public access and use, with the
ability to contain public areas and lock-down student areas after-school.
The cafeteria features four dining areas surrounding a kitchen and serving area that can accommodate 750
students (by SED Standards) – or 1/4 of the expected student population in three servings

page.text: Albany City School District Board of Education
INTRODUCTION - This Scoping Document has been prepared pursuant to Article 8 of the
Environmental Conservation Law and 6 NYCRR Part 617, which are together known as the
State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA). Under SEQRA, the primary goals of the
scoping process are to focus the Draft Environmental Impact Statement (DEIS) on potentially
significant adverse impacts and eliminate consideration of those impacts that are irrelevant or not
significant. The DEIS will address the issues identified in the Final Scoping Document.
The DEIS will provide a means for the Albany City School District Board of Education (the
“Board”), State and local agencies, and the public to systematically consider significant adverse
environmental impacts, alternatives and measures to mitigate environmental impacts related to
the proposed zone change. The DEIS will facilitate the weighing of social, economic, and
environmental factors early in the planning and decision-making process.
To initiate the SEQR process, the Board prepared a Full Environmental Assessment Form
(FEAF), which they circulated to the Involved Agencies for the purpose of declaring themselves
Lead Agency. With no Involved Agencies objecting to the Board’s request, the Board became
Lead Agency on July 17, 2014 and issued a Positive Declaration and adopted a Draft Scoping
Document, which is being circulated to all Involved Agencies.
To allow for public input, the Board has made the Draft Scoping Document available for public
comments on the Draft Scoping Document until August 8th, 2014 and conduct a Public Scoping
, 2014 at 7 pm at Albany High School.
PROJECT HISTORY AND DESCRIPTION – The current Albany High School building was
constructed in 1973; no major renovations have taken place since. While the 317,000 sq.ft.
structure is sound, major infrastructure renovations are required to meet current building and
education code standards. Many of the current building systems, including plumbing, electric
and mechanical, are original and are in need of replacement for proper function and general
Furthermore, hall monitoring, maneuvering and overall building security is difficult to maintain
with the current floor plan and entry way. Existing auditorium space limits play production.
Music classroom space has been used to compensate for inadequate auditorium space. The
library and media center, gymnasium, cafeteria and art rooms are inadequate to house the
appropriate resources and meet school needs.
The existing classrooms do not adequately meet class size, desired room size, or number of
needed rooms. Classroom windows provide little insulation; ventilation within classrooms is
poor, and interior classrooms do not receive natural light. Additional classroom spaces are
required to meet special education needs. Large multi-purpose project areas and hands-on
laboratories, as well as general storage areas are needed throughout the building.
Currently, the Board has not identified a preferred option for a new high school. Options range
from complete renovation to the existing high school, construction of a new high school or a
combination of renovation and new construction. However, regardless of the option, which
could include acquisition of the adjacent four-acre Naval Reserve Parcel, the new Albany High
School will establish two separate houses comprised of five small learning communities. Total
square footage of the new high school could be up 565,000 sq. ft.
Student enrollment for the 2013-2014 school year was 2,288. There are 207 instructional
employees and 71 non-instructional employees who populate the high school. Projected student
enrollment for the 2014-2015 school year is 2,305. The combination of projected enrollment
increases, the district’s effort to increase the graduation rates and the potential closing of charter
high schools will create an overall increase in the student population. Estimated student
enrollment projections range from 2,522 to 3,824 for the 2023-2014 school year based on these
factors. A realistic number for planning is 3,100. Staffing for this student enrollment will
increase by approximately 50 instructional employees and 15 non-instructional employees.
Option A is a combination of new construction and renovations. This option provides two new
main entrances, one along Washington Avenue and another at the rear of the building from the
lower level. The existing courtyard will become a three story interior space with vertical
circulation connecting each level, and will serve as the spine of the building to connect the two
main classroom buildings and specials. The existing classroom building will be renovated to
accommodate the upper school (grades 11 and 12) with two, two story small learning
communities. A new 3 story classroom building along Washington Avenue will be constructed.
This building will house the lower school comprised of grades 9 and 10, with one small learning
community on each floor. A new arts building, situated behind the existing gym will hold
program for performing arts, including a new 1500 seat theater, music and fine arts at the first
Option B is primarily new construction with the exception of the existing gymnasium and
smaller ancillary gymnasiums. The pool will be demolished and rebuilt to provide additional
athletic program space. New construction is planned to the north, south and east of the existing
gymnasiums. The existing classroom building and auditorium will be demolished and two, three
story classroom buildings will house a total of 5 small learning communities. Two main
entrances will be located on each end of a new commons along the first floor. The commons
will connect the classroom buildings as well as a new cafeteria, auditorium and arts building, and
career and technology at the first floor. A main circulation spine overlooking the commons at
the second and third floors connects the classroom building, media center and career and
Entirely new construction is proposed in Option C. The new high school will be constructed to
the south east of the existing gymnasium and pool, along the corner of Washington Avenue and
O’Leary Boulevard. Two new three story classroom buildings will house 5 small learning
communities. A new commons will serve as the main entrance from two points along
Washington Avenue at the first floor level and along the rear of the building at the lower level,
and as the main spine connecting the specials, including a new cafeteria, career and technology
education and a new arts building and athletic complex. A circulation spine at the second and
third floors will overlook the commons and connect the classroom buildings, media center, and
career and technology. A new three story athletic complex will hold a new pool, main
competition gymnasium, auxiliary gym, fitness room, locker rooms and supporting spaces.
Furthermore, in order to meet the needs of a large city school district athletic program,
renovation and construction of the athletic facilities at the high school are required. All of the
existing fields are overused and lack irrigation which has resulted in poor turf conditions. The
tennis courts have been resurfaced but will require more extensive reconstruction in the future.
They also have security concerns because of the lack of visibility. The addition of potential
amenities such as a lighting system, press box, scoreboard, and electronic trimming systems
would increase the quality of play and help make invitational meets more practical.
SITE DESCRIPTION – Albany High School is located on a twenty-seven acre parcel at 700
Washington Avenue. The campus consists of maintained urban lawn space and athletic fields
with the exception of the school building, associated parking space and driveways.
Across from school, along Washington Avenue, the primary land use is residential with a mix of
single family and two family houses. Adjacent to the school at the intersection of North Main
Avenue and Washington Avenue is the four acre Naval Reserve Center, which may be acquired
by the District. Along O’Leary Avenue, which is the east border of the high school campus, is
Beverwyck Park. Along the southern edge of the high school is the Pastoral Center of Roman
DESCRIPTION OF ACTION - The DEIS will analyze the environmental impacts associated
with the renovation and/or reconstruction of the Albany High School .and the acquisition of the
POTENTIAL IMPACTS AND MITIGATION MEASURES – A Full Environmental
Assessment Form (FEAF) was prepared to determine the potential significance of the project
impacts. Based on this initial analysis, the following scope is provided to guide the preparation of
Potential Impact: Reconstruction and/or renovation of Albany High School could change local
traffic and parking patterns. Increases in student, teacher and staff populations could cause an
increase in traffic volumes and busing and parking requirements
Anticipated Information Needed to Address the Impact:
Existing Information Available background traffic and roadway information from the
City of Albany, Capital District Transportation Committee (CDTC) and New York State
Department of Transportation (NYSDOT) will be reviewed. This information could include
previous traffic and parking studies, historical traffic counts, and planned roadway
Required New Information and Methodology for Obtaining Same – Manual traffic counts
will be conducted at the following locations for the weekday a.m. peak (7-9 am) and the
 Washington Avenue and West Erie Street
 Washington Avenue and AHS Parking Lot Access 1
 Washington Avenue and AHS Parking Lot Access 2
 North Main Avenue, Chestnut Street and AHS Access
 West Erie Street and Kent Street
Within the vicinity of the Site, safety issues such as sight distance, pedestrian crossings and
emergency vehicle access will be reviewed. Pedestrian and transit accommodations and
connectivity to existing and proposed adjacent land uses and associated features will be reviewed
Existing campus parking facilities will be reviewed from aerial photos and a site visit to identify
locations, capacity and designated uses. Field visits will be conducted during weekday periods to
identify the general utilization of the existing parking supply. This will consist of a general
windshield survey of the area generally defined as Washington Avenue, North Allen Street,
Manning Boulevard, Kent Street, Ontario Street and Lancaster Street, before, during and after
school hours to note the changes in parking occupancy.
Where the analysis indicates congested operations, changes in level of service or off-site parking
supply, improvements will be identified to mitigate the impacts and to accommodate the
projected traffic flows. Existing and future queuing space for CDTA busses will be reviewed to
ensure that it provides safe access for students.
Initial Identification of Mitigation Measures: If the capacity analysis described above indicates a
decline in the operating conditions of the surrounding road system, potential improvements will
be evaluated and recommended to mitigate the impacts and to accommodate the projected traffic
flows. These improvements may include roadway improvements, traffic calming techniques,
new turning lanes, upgraded or new traffic signals, and pedestrian amenities including sidewalks
Potential Impact: A 2005 Phase 1A Archeological Sensitivity Assessment for concluded the site
is moderately sensitive to historic resources because of past structures and a cemetery that
Anticipated Information Necessary to Address the Impact:
Existing Information- Phase1A Archeological Sensitivity Assessment prepared by
Required New Information and Methodology for Obtaining Same – Update the
previously prepared Phase 1A Archeological Survey by a qualified professional
archeologist to review the literature regarding the potential occurrence of historic
resources within the Site. The files of the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation
and Historic Preservation and the New York State Museum will be reviewed. A
preliminary field investigation will also be completed.
Initial Identification of Mitigation Measures: Mitigation measures could include completion of
Phase IB and Phase II archeological investigations and Phase 3 Data Recovery Plan.
Investigations and recommendations will be reviewed and approved by the New York State
Office of Parks, Recreation, and Historic Preservation. Mitigation measures could include
removal of artifacts prior to construction.
Potential Impact: The City of Albany Police Department and Department of Fire and Emergency
Services would provide police, fire and EMS services for Albany High School. The
renovation/reconstruction of the High School is not expected to significantly affect the ability of
the agencies to maintain public safety.
Anticipated Information Necessary to Address the Impact:
Required New Information and Methodology for Obtaining Same - The City of Albany
Police Department and Department of Fire and Emergency Services will be contacted
regarding existing resources and potential concerns.
Initial Identification of Mitigation Measures: It will be necessary to ensure that the facility is
accessible by police, fire and EMS vehicles. The new building should be designed with
sufficient lighting to protect public safety.
Potential Impact: The project would likely require new connections to the water, wastewater, and
stormwater infrastructure of the City of Albany. The combination of new and/or renovated
buildings would likely change the amount of water usage and wastewater and stormwater
generated. Depending on the increase, the capacity of these systems could be impacted.
Moreover, existing utilities could be temporarily impacted during construction if they require
Anticipated Information Necessary to Address the Impact:
Existing Information- Record mapping from the Albany Water Board and the Albany
Required New Information and Methodology for Obtaining Same – Topographic and
utility survey of the Site and adjoining area
Initial Identification of Mitigation Measures: It is not known at this time if improvements to the
water and sanitary sewer would be required to support the renovated/reconstructed Albany High
To mitigate impacts associated with the increase in stormwater runoff, it is expected that
recommendation and standards will be provided for construction in conformance with NYSDEC
Stormwater Management Design Manual (August 2010). Compliance with NYSDEC
Construction Activity Permit (SPDES GP-0-10-001) and/or the MS4 Stormwater Discharge
Permit (SPDES GP-0-10-002) will also mitigate potential stormwater related impacts.
Combined stormwater and sanitary sewer (CSO’s) that are directly impacted by construction
would be separated. Sustainable design and building techniques to reduce water consumption,
wastewater generation and energy consumption will also be identified. Recommendation will
also be provided to incorporate Low Impact Development (LID) techniques to reduce stormwater
Potential Impact: Potential air quality impacts include increased air emissions from student, staff
teacher and delivery vehicles entering the Albany High School facility.
Anticipated Information Needed to Address the Impact
Existing Information – Review NYSDEC Ambient Air Quality Data available from the
Required New Information and Methodology for Obtaining Same – Impacts on air
quality will be assessed qualitatively through a review of existing air quality data, future
traffic levels, and proximity of sensitive air receptors (e.g. hospital, schools, etc). An air
quality model or quantitative assessment of air quality impacts will not be completed.
Initial Identification of Mitigation Measures: Carpooling programs to minimize single occupancy
vehicles (SOV) miles. Complete traffic improvements to maintain acceptable levels of services
Potential Impact: The football fields will be constructed and competition level sports lighting
will be provided. New lighting has the potential to reflect light and spill onto adjacent
Anticipated Information Necessary to Address the Impact:
Required New Information and Methodology for Obtaining Same – Review adjacent land
uses to identify light sensitive uses. Identify lighting technology options for the football field.
Initial Identification of Mitigation Measures: Require the use of dark sky friendly lighting that
minimizes glare and spillage on adjacent properties.
Potential Impact: The construction period for Albany High School could be as long sixty months.
Construction may require the relocation of some of the existing water, sewer, natural gas, electric
and telecom infrastructure within the site. Construction staging for materials, equipment and
employee parking will be needed and further complicated by the need to maintain athletic field
use during construction on small site and urban street grid.
Construction and demolition activities will generate increased levels of noise and diesel exhaust,
especially during the early stages of construction when demolition, earthwork, foundation
construction, and steel work are being completed. Construction vehicles also have the potential
to track soil and sediment onto adjacent streets while soils are still exposed. Grading and
excavation activities will expose soils to stormwater runoff, which increases the potential for
Existing buildings on site are likely to contain asbestos. In addition the Naval Reserve Parcel is
listed on the NYSDEC Environmental Site Remediation Data Base. Contaminated soils were
removed in 1991 and in 2005. Monitoring wells were installed in 2012.
Anticipated Information Needed to Address the Impact
Existing Information – NYSDEC Environmental Site Remediation Data Base records.
Records indicate that groundwater contamination appears to be confined to on-site areas.
Required New Information and Methodology for Obtaining Same – Complete a field
review of Site and surrounding area to determine to assess land uses that may be sensitive
to short term impacts on truck traffic, noise and air quality.
Initial Identification of Mitigation Measures: All construction equipment should be properly
tuned and maintained to minimize noise and air impacts. Use of low sulfur and/or bio diesel
fuels by construction vehicles would also minimize air impacts.
Frequent watering of construction areas would be required to minimize dust. Sweeping and
cleaning of streets and access driveways would also be done to minimize the amount of fugitive
dust. Sediment and erosion control techniques required in accordance with the Phase II SPDES
Permit for Construction Activities will be identified.
If utility relocations result in temporary disruptions in service, the work should be completed
during hours when users would be least impacted (i.e. nights or weekends, depending on user).
Measures to maintain traffic and pedestrian circulation and safety during construction will be
Conduct a Phase 1 Environmental Site Assessment prior to construction to verify presence of
asbestos and other environmental issues related to potential groundwater and soil contamination.
Abate and/or remediate in accordance with state and federal regulations prior to the start of
1. No Action - the "no action" alternative will evaluate the impacts on the City of Albany and
the District if a new Albany High School is not constructed.
2. Alternative Size – Alternatively sized facilities on the Site will be evaluated.
